title: EU spat with AstraZeneca throws spotlight on vaccine supplies
text:
The FT is offering a free 30-day trial to Coronavirus Business Update, which includes access to FT.com. Please spread the word by forwarding this newsletter to friends and colleagues who you think would find it valuable. And if this has been forwarded to you, hello. Please sign up here

Latest news

For up-to-the-minute coronavirus updates visit our live blog

  • Prime minister Boris Johnson has announced that schools in England will not reopen until March 8 at the earliest

  • AT&T announced $650m in Covid charges as it reported a fourth-quarter loss

  • Growth in US durable goods orders slowed in December as coronavirus restrictions were tightened

Brussels considers export curbs on vaccines made in EU

The EU today upped the ante in its battle with AstraZeneca over vaccine supplies by insisting the pharma company should meet shortfalls in its delivery pledges with supplies from its UK plants.

The spat highlights growing fears of shortages around the world, a situation underlined in an IMF report published today that said limited access to jabs in emerging markets posed a threat to global financial stability. 

Brussels' fight with AstraZeneca, which follows similar supply problems with the BioNTech/Pfizer jab, culminated yesterday in calls for tighter restrictions on vaccines leaving the bloc. Jens Spahn, Germany's health minister, urged Brussels to force companies to obtain permission before shipping jabs from the bloc.

Pascal Soriot, chief executive of Anglo-Swedish AstraZeneca, described the company's delivery schedule as a “best effort” rather than a “commitment”, further enraging Brussels officials already angry at what it sees as the unfair priority given by the company to its UK orders.

EU tensions were heightened today when the regional governments of Madrid and Catalonia complained of supply shortages. Madrid said it was halting its vaccination programme for at least 10 days because of a lack of supplies and Catalonia warned it could run out of the vaccine by Thursday.

French pharmaceuticals group Sanofi said today it would accelerate production of the BioNTech/Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine and add millions to the EU supply.

The EU has faced frequent criticism over its failure to get the vaccine into the arms of its citizens quicker. The UK, by contrast, has now vaccinated (with the first of two shots) more than a tenth of its population and the US has also made a strong start.

The Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine has yet to be formally approved by the European Medicines Agency, the bloc's regulator, and Brussels has been less supportive of financial research support for pharma groups, the FT's Lex column points out.

But the frustration with government vaccination programmes is not confined to the EU. In Brazil, a group of companies dismayed at the slow rollout of vaccines has looked at buying doses directly from manufacturers. In the US, private sector companies including Amazon, Walmart and Starbucks have offered to help the new Biden administration accelerate distribution.

One exception is Israel, which has managed to secure more vaccine than it needs after agreeing to share the country's epidemiological data with manufacturer Pfizer. 

The FT, however, cautions against “vaccine nationalism”. Export bans “risk retaliation from other trading partners, disrupt supply chains and do little to expand overall vaccine production, which must be the common goal”, the Editorial Board said (you can read more on the proposals in our explainer).

Bookmark this: More than 71m coronavirus jabs have now been administered in 65 countries. Check out our revamped vaccine tracker for more.

Markets

Sky-high valuations of tech companies that enable working from home or provide locked-down consumers with gadgets are driving a debate about how best to value a company as some analysts warned of a bubble ready to burst. “Nobody cares if you're profitable these days,” said the head of one large hedge fund.

Company fundraising through bonds and equities has rocketed as stimulus measures boost global markets and is about $170bn above normal levels for this time of year, according to a FT analysis of data from Refinitiv.

Robert Buckland, chief global equity strategist at Citigroup, writes for the FT on lessons from the market bubbles of the past. But he disagrees with the notion that “this crazy bubble will burst soon”. “We've stopped dancing, we are standing closer to the door, but we haven't left the party yet,” he writes.

Read more in our ongoing Runaway Markets series.

Business

Jumps in sales of PCs, video-gaming demand and increased use of Microsoft's cloud services helped the company's revenues surge 17 per cent to $43.1bn in the fourth quarter and its shares to hit an all-time high. Chief executive Satya Nadella said the pandemic had led to “the dawn of a second wave of digital transformation sweeping every company and every industry”.

Reduced demand for air travel was part of the reason airline manufacturer Boeing reported a record annual loss of almost $12bn and postponed the introduction of its new 777X jet until late 2023. Cash outflows at Rolls-Royce, which makes aeroplane engines, will hit $2bn this year. Total flying hours for its engines this year are expected to be just above half pre-pandemic levels.

Fears over new variants of coronavirus have thrown the spotlight on to how quickly drugmakers can adapt their vaccines. Pharma correspondent Hannah Kuchler and science reporter Anna Gross explain how development times are shrinking.

Global economy

Updated global forecasts from the IMF show the US and China leading the race for economic recovery, leaving Europe and EMs in their wake. “Faster progress on ending the health crisis will raise global income cumulatively by $9tn over 2020 to 2025, with benefits for all countries, including around $4tn for advanced economies,” the fund said in its latest global economy forecasts. The UK — which yesterday passed the milestone of 100,000 deaths from the disease — will fare particularly badly, the IMF said, and would not recover lost output until 2023.

French finance minister Bruno Le Maire told the FT that the EU's €750bn recovery fund was “too slow and complicated”. Member states need to explain how they will use the grants and loans by the end of April and once approved by the European Commission they can be disbursed in the second half of the year. Germany's former finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble said the EU had spent too much time arguing about the size of the fund and how it should be distributed, and not enough “thinking about what to spend it on”. Germany today cut its forecasts for growth while separate data showed consumer confidence in Germany and France had plunged.

US President Joe Biden said for the first time he was ready for compromise on his $1.9tn coronavirus recovery plan, possibly lowering the income threshold for people to receive another round of stimulus cheques. The US Federal Reserve is meeting for the first time this year to decide interest rates — the first under the new president — as it reviews economic progress. It will issue a statement today at 2pm ET: here are five things to watch.

Have your say

Reader NotBillGates comments on Retail has a place on the UK high street of the future:

Business rates are not fit for purpose in a post-digital economy. However, there would appear to be a couple of easy fixes:
1. Conduct the overdue rating revaluation now to recognise the shift in value that has occurred from retail to industrial and logistics property which would significantly redress the outdated burden placed on retail property.
2. Introduce a congestion charge for delivery vehicles that enter urban areas to reflect the changing nature of commerce. It's fair, easy to enforce and in line with local authorities' stated objective of reducing carbon emissions in urban areas.

Final thought

Itching for some adventure after months of lockdown? Read How To Spend It's recommendations for ultra-sporting challenges, from cycling in the Alps to racing across the Grand Canyon.

We would really like to hear from you. Please send your reactions or suggestions to covid@ft.com. Thanks
